SummaryOfEvents:
In the morning on 23 January 2003, in restricted visibility and rough weather,  a Hong Kong registered ship “ Top Glory” and a  German registered  ship “Ville d’Orion” collided at sea at the approximate position of 26° 52’ N 160° 47.5’ W, about 265 nautical miles north west of Kauai of the Hawaii Islands. “Top Glory sustained structural damages at the bow as a result of the collision while “Ville d’Orion” sustained damages at the port side amidships side shell. There was no injury to the crew in this incident. 

After the collision “Ville d’Orion” made an unscheduled port call to Honolulu for temporary repairs and “Top Glory” continued its voyage to Japan. Both ships arrived to their destinations safety.

SOLASStatus: EBRO: Unknown/unspecified, P&O NEDLLOYD GENOA: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
With a visibility of less than 500m and dense fog the United Kingdom registered container vessel P&O NEDLLOYD GENOA travelling upstream along the River Elbe, coming from Rotterdam, collided at about 09.32h on 19 December 2002 with the Portuguese chemical tanker EBRO, travelling downstream along the River Elbe, coming from Bützfleth, between buoys 78 and 80.  EBRO struck P&O NEDLLOYD GENOA on its aft starboard side in the stern area at a height of approx. 6m above the waterline over a length of approx. 25m and a width of approx. 2 to 3m.  The damage consisted of heavy paint abrasion and denting, as well as minor holes in the hull on a level with the frames. As a result of the collision the container vessel became stranded on a level with buoy 80 at river km 675.5.  After it came free with the rising tide at about 11.25h, the vessel was able to continue its voyage. On EBRO the starboard bulwark was set in over a length of 10 to 12m.  Furthermore, two frames in the foreship area were cracked/torn.  The vessel continued its voyage.
No personal injuries were sustained and there was no water ingress.  No tanks were damaged and therefore there was no environmental pollution. Only property damage was sustained.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 8 December 2002, MA CHO arrived in Devonport to discharge a part cargo of fertiliser at no. 4 berth on the western side of the river.
On 9 December 2002, the Master made the decision to conduct an abandon ship drill before the vessel was due to depart for Geelong.  The drill commenced at about 1540 and the starboard lifeboat was prepared for lowering to the water.
At approximately 1548 the Mate reported that the crew inside the lifeboat were seated and had fastened their safety belts.  Lowering of the boat commenced with one of the crew operating the davit winch brake from the deck.  When the boat had been lowered approximately two meters from the davit head the after on-load release hook suddenly opened, releasing the after fall.  The lifeboat's stern fell to leave the boat suspended vertically by the remaining forward fall with its stern swinging approximately five meters above the water.  The boat crew were shaken by the incident but remained secured in their seats inside the now vertical lifeboat.  The second mate had sustained a small cut over his left eye.
After the crew had disembarked, the lifeboat was lowered to the water to allow the on-load release system to be inspected.

The engine stopped and the rudder moved to starboard.  The engine was run astern to try but the ship remained aground. The position at which she grounded was Latitude 57°29’N Longitude 11°16’E and the weather was calm.  A salvage tug came alongside at 07:20 hours and the ship was successfully refloated at 12:22 hours on 16 November 2002.

SummaryOfEvents:
The MV INDONESIA STAR disembarked the Panama Canal pilot at 0240 on 19 October 2002 after transiting the Panama Canal.

At 0542 while the vessel was on passage, the stern tube started to loose the lubricating oil.

The crew investigated this oil loss and tried to control the situation. They were not successful and water started to leak into the engine room from the inner stern tube seals.

The master of the vessel contacted the owners and advised of the danger of the engine room flooding with water through the leaking stern tube.

The main engine was stopped and the vessel was left to drift and tug assistance was requested.

On 21 October 2002 at 0630, the tugboat OLYMPIA of TSAVLIRIS SALVAGE secured the tow and took the MV INDONESIA STAR under tow.

The vessels arrived at Kingston roads were the MV INDONESIA STAR anchored.  Later on the vessel was dry-docked and repairs affected at Curacao.

SummaryOfEvents: During the sailing in hard storm (30-34 m/sec.) conditions, unsafe value of the ship stability parameters and the destruction of lashing were observed. At 09:45 (05:45 UTC) in high waves (8-10 m.) there was a shift and rollover of cargo (16 railway wagons with oil) to the starboard. As a result, a critical list (45-50°) and a fire on cargo deck (observed heavy black smoke) occurred. In such circumstances, the launching of survival craft were impossible. Due to the impact of high waves, the list of the ship gradually increased. At 10:30 (06:30 UTC) 22.10.2002 the ship capsized and sank in 10 minutes at position 40° 05' 65" N and 51° 29' 47" in 149 m. depth.  4 persons dead and 37 persons missing.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 31st August 2002 the fishing vessel TAMARA left Southport, Australia, en route to Noumea, a voyage of 750 miles. The autopilot was not functioning, so the skipper shared the steering duties with the deckhand, the only other crew member on board. At about 16.00 hours LT on 1st September  the skipper noticed that the engine was losing power, and saw black smoke coming from the hatches, but could not locate the source of the problem. He decided to turn TAMARA's head to the sea, but as the vessel turned a huge wave washed over the stern and a large amount of water was trapped on the work deck. This flowed quickly into the open steering hatch and through into the ice room and engine room. The mechanical and electrical bilge pumps were operated, but they could not keep up with the rapid inflow of water, and it became evideent that the vessel was going to sink. Both men dived into the sea, and watched the vessel sink. Shortly afterwards the liferaft stowed on the wheel house surfaced and the two men climbed into it. The life raft held a survival pack which kept them going for many days, but despite ships coming into view none of them noticed the flares that the two men set off and it was not until 9th September, when the skipper's friend reported that the TAMARA  was overdue at Nournea, that rescue services were alerted. However, it was not until 14 September 2002 that the two men were found drifting in a liferaft 30 miles east of Moreton Island,  Queensland, by the fishing vessel Devocean. The authorities were contacted and the men were subsequently airlifted to hospital in Brisbane.

SummaryOfEvents:
In fair weather and good visibility, the loaded bulk carrier was downbound off Verchères, Québec under the conduct of a pilot.  In the late afternoon, the bosun and another crew member were securing the port lifeboat ready for sea.  The bosun was sitting on a davit cradle securing the trigger line when the lifeboat suddenly released and struck him on its descent.  He then lost his grip and fell backwards into the water. 
The alarm was raised and several life rings were thrown to the bosun's aid. Auxiliary search and rescue crafts were quickly on the scene, but the bosun could not be found. His body was recovered five days later. The cause of death was drowning.

Location: 7 miles off the coast of Aruba, Netherlands Antilles
SummaryOfEvents: On July 16, 2002 the Liberian registered oil tanker CRUDE OCEAN experienced  a steam explosion on board while the vessel was in anchorage off the coast of Aruba, Netherlands Antilles.  The explosion occurred at 11:30LT and sadly resulted in the death of two officers, the Chief Engineer and the Second Engineer.  Additionally, the Fitter was severely burned and had to be evacuated to receive medical treatment.  It was reported that the explosion happened as the Chief Officer and Second Officer were attempting to open a steam valve that had been stuck and not working properly.  Their proximity to the steam line led to their being fatally scalded and thrown through the engine room.  Because the Fitter was standing further away, he was able to survive the blast.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 7 July 2002, the Belgian beam trawler Flamingo sank just inside UK waters to the east of Harwich. Her crew of four was lost. That evening, she had been fishing in the company of three other Belgian trawlers but, at 22:53 hours; Thames Coastguard was informed of an EPIRB alert from the ship. She could not be contacted and a search and rescue operation began immediately
Flamingo’s upturned hull was located, and the bodies of two of the four crew members were picked up. Neither was wearing a lifejacket.
The hull drifted with the tide until the following afternoon, when it was attempted to tow her towards a nearby sandbank, with the intention of beaching her.
She sank shortly after the tow began

SummaryOfEvents:
The vessel was en route from UK to Klaipeda. The captain asked the Danish pilot station in Skagen about the draft under the East Bridge. At the pilot station they thought that the vessel planned to pass under the East part of the bridge over the Great Belt in Danish water. The pilot station therefore informed the captain that the draft was 17m.
As the Eleni was en route under the bridge in the Flintrannan Channel the vessel grounded.
The vessels draft was 9.45 m and the dredged draft under the bridge in the Flintrannan Channel is 8.4m.

SummaryOfEvents:
In the morning of 10 April 2002, an evacuation drill was conducted aboard the passenger ferry M/S VISBY, while she was at the quay in Visby port.  
The purpose of the drill was to demonstrate the vessel's safety organisation to the Swedish Maritime Safety Inspectorate.  In particular it was to be shown how in an emergency situation passengers could be evacuated from the passenger accommodation on deck 2, which is below the vehicle deck.  On board were a full crew and a group of observers from the Maritime Safety Inspectorate.  In addition, the shipping company had engaged 318 supernumeraries who were to act as passengers.
When the supernumeraries and observers had taken their places on board, the drill started with the fiction that a fire had broken out in an engine-room at the bottom of the vessel.  In the introductory phase the crew were alerted and a fire-fighting group was sent out to engage the fire.  The passengers were informed that the ship was to be evacuated.  Closure of the vessel's watertight doors (WT doors) was activated from the bridge, whereupon two doors that were open, shut automatically.  These were located in the passenger area on deck 2.
When the fire-fighting group arrived in the engine-room they discovered a man standing caught in a WT door.  He was released and life-saving measures were started.  However, he was found to be dead.  The dead man was an electrical engineer, well familiar with the vessel and with the operation of its WT doors.  He was employed temporarily to carry out electrical work.

Eastern approach jetty to Immingham locks
SummaryOfEvents:
At 0020 on 2 April 2002, the Swedish registered ro-ro vessel Stena Gothica struck the eastern jetty, during a spring ebb tide, while approaching Immingham lock.  A 3 metre gash was sustained in the port side shell plating below the water line leading to a large ingress of water into the lower cargo hold.
The vessel was moved into the lock and shortly after, began to list to starboard, reaching a maximum heel of 14.5° at 0333. Firefighters and a local salvage team attended and , after several hours, the ingress of water was slowed and the water level in the lower hold reduced. The quick and effective action of the firefighters and salvors prevented a capsize.
The vessel was moved to berth no4 where she was all fast at 1442. An MAIB inspector arrived at the vessel shortly after she berthed to commence the investigation.

SummaryOfEvents:
On the afternoon of 17 March 2002, while stopped in ice and waiting for a change in the weather, a fire broke out in the bow of the large fishing vessel KATSHESHUK.  After an unsuccessful attempt at fighting the fire, the decision was made to abandon the vessel.
Several days later, the tug ATLANTIC MAPLE took the vessel into tow and steamed towards St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador.  The tug and tow encountered adverse weather and were forced to seek refuge in Trinity Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador.  When the weather finally moderated, the tow resumed.  On the morning of 30 March 2002, while approximately six nautical miles north-west of Cape St. Francis, Newfoundland and Labrador, the KATSHESHUK listed and sank in position 47º54.3'N, 052º49.5'W.
One crew member suffered a broken foot when he fell off the pilot ladder. A second crew member suffered a lacerated hand when he came in contact with some broken glass while retrieving a fire axe.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Serious injuries

Location: Off Cape St. Francis, South Africa

SOLASStatus: PRAIRIE SKY: Unknown/unspecified, STOLT PERSEVERANCE: Unknown/unspecified

Location: In traffic separation S. of Falsterbo
SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel GULDBORG was on its way home on a northern course east of the traffic separation gyratory near Falsterborev. The skipper who was on watch went down to the engine room to grease and he did not returtn to the wheelhouse until just before the collision. The tug BIZON was proceeding on a westerly course ot the gyratory, when the collision occured. BIZON was towing a large loaded barge and showed navigation lights as a vessel restricted in its ability to manoeuvre. The skipper on the fishing vessel had seen the tug and the barge on the radar before he went down in the engine room, but he estimated that the fishing vessel would pass aft of the tug and barge. GULDBORG hit the port side of the barge and sank short after the collision. The crew of the GULDBORG boarded the liferaft and was later picked up by BIZON.

SOLASStatus: A.M.  VELLA: Unknown/unspecified, KOTA HADIAH: Unknown/unspecified
Location: Kap Shui Channel, S.E. of Ha Pang light
SummaryOfEvents:
The Singapore registered container  ship “Kota Hadiah” collided with a Hong Kong  local licensed dredger “A.M. Vella”. The collision took place in good weather condition. 

“Kota Hadiah” sustained minor damage at the bulbous bow while “A.M. Vella” capsized to port and sank subsequently after being hit at the starboard   side in way of the machinery space. Eight crew members from “A.M. Vella” were lost in the incident.

Location: Near New Ross, river Barrow, county Wexford
SummaryOfEvents: The coastal tanker motor vessel « Whithaven » grounded outbound from New Ross, Co. Wexford 2002 at approximately 01:33 hours GMT. The ship was refloated on the next high water and had suffered bottom hull penetration and damage. There were no apparent injuries to anyone

SummaryOfEvents:
After departing Odda, with a pilot on board, a fire broke out in the engine room. The fire was extinguished by the crew with the assistance from tugs providing water and the vessel was towed to port.
One crew member was evacuated by helicopter for medical treatment.
The vessel was later declared a constructive total loss.

SummaryOfEvents:
On the evening of 2 February 2002 the Irish registered fishing ship “Celestial Dawn” with a crew of ten, sailed from Dingle at approximately 18:45 hour’s local time. At approximately 19:00 hours the ship went aground on the rocks near the lighthouse on the East side if Dingle Bay. 
There were no fatalities or injuries

During route navigation from Ronne to Copenhagen with 240 passengers and 32 crewmembers a fire arose in the engine room. The ships was four nautical miles south of Drogden light. 

The fire was efficiently exstinguished with an fixed high pressure water mist system. After the ship had been made ready, the ship continued its voyage towards Copenhagen by its own engine power.

The cause of fire was a leakage on a fuel oil reurn pipe on a main engine from where emitting oil had been ignited by the hot surface of the motor's exhaust system.

Location: About 2 cables S. of Newhaven east pier
English channel, about 20 miles from Falmouth
SummaryOfEvents: On 1 February 2002, the Maltese, 6395gt cargo ship Kodima was passage from Sweden to Libya. Between 19:00 hours and 19:50 hours her deck cargo shifted to port causing a list of 15° and, although course was altered towards Falmouth Bay, England, the list, compounding by  the  ship rolling in heavy seas, continued to increase. By 04:50 hours the following morning it has reached 40°, and the ship’s main engine and generators had become inoperable. With the ship stopped in the water about 20 miles from Falmouth, and drifting to the north-east, the master and crew were evacuated by helicopter. Attempt to secure a towline were unsuccessful, and Kodima eventually grounded on Tregantle Beach, Whitsands Bay at 18:55.

SummaryOfEvents: During towing of a split barge together with another Danish towboat in the Elbe in strong oncomming current, the ship capsized as they were turning a little to port in order to get over to another side of the river. The master and the officer fell into the water and when the ship had come aligned, the master was still at the ship but the officer had got away from the ship. The engine was still running, and the master managed to rescue the officer.
